DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Yugo Reorganization
DOC.TEXT: A reorganization plan for Yugo America Inc., the importer of small Yugoslavian-made automobiles, has been approved by a federal bankruptcy judge. Under the plan approved Wednesday by Judge Vincent J. Commisa, Yugo America will become a wholly owned subsidiary of the Yugoslav automaker Zastava. ``The direct ownership by Zastava of Yugo America Inc. is expected to provide the U.S. sales arm with the financial strength and marketing commitment required to firmly establish the Yugo in the American market,'' Yugo America President John Spiech said. The unsecured creditors, which are owed an estimated $24 million, will receive 9 cents on the dollar, said Robert Baine, attorney for Impex Car Corp., a U.S. agent for Zastava. The Yugo dealers will be paid back the entire $7 million owed them, Baine said. Yugo's chief bank lender, Manufacturer's Hanover Trust in New York, will receive all $1.6 million it is owed. Baine said that YugoBank, one of Yugoslavia's national banks, has committed up to $24 million in credit to the company. Yugo America, based in Upper Saddle River, N.J., filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws on Jan. 30 along with its then-parent company Global Motors Inc. and sister company Proton America. While the case was pending in bankruptcy court, Yugo continued to sell cars. Yugo cars first went on sale in August 1985 for $3,995. Sales during the first 10 months of this year were 9,193, down 78.1 percent from the same period in 1987, when sales were at their highest rate. The reorganization, Spiech said, clears the way for the company to offer a convertible and a new model line.
